name: Stdout
comment:
dart-io.Stdout exposes methods to query the terminal for properties.

Use dart-io.Stdout.hasTerminal to test if there is a terminal associated to stdout.

encoding.name: encoding
encoding.comment: The dart-convert.Encoding used when writing strings. Depending on the underlying consumer this property might be mutable.

hasTerminal.name: hasTerminal
hasTerminal.comment: Returns true if there is a terminal attached to stdout.

terminalColumns.name: terminalColumns
terminalColumns.comment:
Get the number of columns of the terminal.

If no terminal is attached to stdout, a dart-io.StdoutException is thrown. See dart-io.Stdout.hasTerminal for more info.

terminalLines.name: terminalLines
terminalLines.comment:
Get the number of lines of the terminal.

If no terminal is attached to stdout, a dart-io.StdoutException is thrown. See dart-io.Stdout.hasTerminal for more info.

done.name: done
done.comment: Get a future that will complete when the consumer closes, or when an error occurs. This future is identical to the future returned by dart-io.Stdout.close.

hashCode.name: hashCode
hashCode.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality operator ==. Other than that there are no guarantees about the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides dart-io.Stdout.hashCode it should override the equality operator as well to maintain consistency.

runtimeType.name: runtimeType
runtimeType.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.

==.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all dart-core.Objects is to return true if and only if this and dart-io.Stdout.==.other are the same object.

Override this method to specify a different equality relation on a class. The overriding method must still be an equivalence relation. That is, it must be:

  • Total: It must return a boolean for all arguments. It should never throw or return null.

  • Reflexive: For all objects o, o == o must be true.

  • Symmetric: For all objects o1 and o2, o1 == o2 and o2 == o1 must either both be true, or both be false.

  • Transitive: For all objects o1, o2, and o3, if o1 == o2 and o2 == o3 are true, then o1 == o3 must be true.

The method should also be consistent over time, so equality of two objects should not change over time, or at least only change if one of the objects was modified.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override the dart-io.Stdout.hashCode method as well to maintain consistency.

add.name: add
add.comment:
Adds dart-io.Stdout.add.data to the target consumer, ignoring dart-io.IOSink.encoding.

The dart-io.IOSink.encoding does not apply to this method, and the data list is passed directly to the target consumer as a stream event.

This function must not be called when a stream is currently being added using dart-io.Stdout.addStream.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.Stdout.flush or dart-io.Stdout.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

The data list should not be modified after it has been passed to add.

addError.name: addError
addError.comment:
Passes the error to the target consumer as an error event.

This function must not be called when a stream is currently being added using dart-io.Stdout.addStream.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.Stdout.flush or dart-io.Stdout.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

addStream.name: addStream
addStream.comment: Adds all elements of the given dart-io.Stdout.addStream.stream to this.

flush.name: flush
flush.comment:
Returns a dart-async.Future that completes once all buffered data is accepted by the to underlying dart-async.StreamConsumer.

It's an error to call this method, while an dart-io.Stdout.addStream is incomplete.

NOTE: This is not necessarily the same as the data being flushed by the operating system.

noSuchMethod.name: noSuchMethod
noSuchMethod.comment:
dart-io.Stdout.noSuchMethod is invoked when users invoke a non-existent method on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the invocation are passed to dart-io.Stdout.noSuchMethod in an dart-core.Invocation. If dart-io.Stdout.noSuchMethod returns a value, that value becomes the result of the original invocation.

The default behavior of dart-io.Stdout.noSuchMethod is to throw a dart-core.NoSuchMethodError.

toString.name: toString
toString.comment: Returns a string representation of this object.

write.name: write
write.comment:
Converts dart-io.Stdout.write.obj to a String by invoking dart-io.Stdout.toString and dart-io.Stdout.adds the encoding of the result to the target consumer.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.Stdout.flush or dart-io.Stdout.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeAll.name: writeAll
writeAll.comment:
Iterates over the given dart-io.Stdout.writeAll.objects and dart-io.Stdout.writes them in sequence.

If dart-io.Stdout.writeAll.separator is provided, a write with the separator is performed between any two elements of objects.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.Stdout.flush or dart-io.Stdout.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeCharCode.name: writeCharCode
writeCharCode.comment:
Writes the dart-io.Stdout.writeCharCode.charCode to this.

This method is equivalent to write(new String.fromCharCode(charCode)).

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.Stdout.flush or dart-io.Stdout.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.

writeln.name: writeln
writeln.comment:
Converts dart-io.Stdout.writeln.obj to a String by invoking dart-io.Stdout.toString and writes the result to this, followed by a newline.

This operation is non-blocking. See dart-io.Stdout.flush or dart-io.Stdout.done for how to get any errors generated by this call.
